Courses.Name: PATHOL 2420A - PATHOLOGY FOR NURSING STUDENTS
Description: A survey course providing an understanding of fundamental mechanisms of disease processes. The first half of the course presents pathogenesis of diseases common to all organ systems; the second half concentrates on disease in most of the major organ systems including cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, genitourinary, nervous and musculoskeletal systems.
Antirequisite(s): The former Pathology 3240A.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours/wk or equivalent online delivery with 1 tutorial hour/wk.  Enrollment limited to students in the Western Fanshawe College collaborative BScN program.

Notes: ONLINE COURSE. RESTRICTED TO WESTERN/FANSHAWE COLLABORATIVE NURSING PROGRAM STUDENTS. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
ONLINE COURSE. RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS IN WESTERN COMPRESSED TIME FRAME NURSING PROGRAM. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 3500 - HUMAN PATHOLOGY
Description: An introduction to human pathology - the study of disease. Students will be introduced to general mechanisms of disease (e.g. inflammation, injury, neoplasia, disturbed hemodynamics). These general processes will be described and applied to specific diseases of organ systems.
Antirequisite(s): Pathology 2420A, the former Pathology 3240A, the former Pathology 3245B.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours.

Notes: PRIORITY INFORMATION IS ON BMSc WEBSITE:  http://www.schulich.uwo.ca/bmsc/academic_resources/courses/access_to_courses.html. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 2280A; Biology 2382A/B.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 3700G - BIOMEDICAL/PATHOLOGY RESEARCH
Description: The focus is on the various research approaches, disease models, experimental designs, and analytical methods used to study and evaluate human disease. The course will use contemporary learning tools and a variety of evaluation and assessment methods. Examples will be taken from major diseases such as cancer and neurodegenerative disorders.
Antirequisite(s): Anatomy and Cell Biology 3700F/G.
Extra Information: 3 lecture/tutorial hours per week.
Cross-listed with Anatomy and Cell Biology 3700F/G.

Notes: BLENDED COURSE: ASYNCHRONOUS ONLINE LECTURE; IN-PERSON TUTORIAL. PRIORITY INFORMATION IS ON BMSc WEBSITE:  http://www.schulich.uwo.ca/bmsc/academic_resources/courses/access_to_courses.html. CROSS-LISTED WITH ANATOMY AND CELL BIOLOGY 3700G. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 2280A and registration in a BMSc degree.
Pre-or Corequisite(s): Pathology 3500 or the former Pathology 3240A; Physiology 3120 or Physiology 3140A.
WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 4200A - PATHOGENESIS OF HUMAN DISEASES
Description: This course will cover current concepts in the molecular and cellular pathogenesis of selected human diseases. These will include endocrine, metabolic, neuropsychiatric, renal, cardiac and neoplastic diseases, with emphasis on defects in genes and/or the levels of hormones or growth factor receptors, cellular organelles, intracellular signaling pathways, and cellular metabolism.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours.

Notes: PRIORITY INFORMATION IS ON BMSc WEBSITE:  http://www.schulich.uwo.ca/bmsc/academic_resources/courses/access_to_courses.html. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Pathology 3500 with a mark of at least 70% or the former Pathology 3240A and the former Pathology 3245B with a mark of at least 70% in each.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 4400B - ENVIRONMENTAL PATHOLOGY
Description: The pathology of occupational and environmental diseases, including information on recent developments and basic mechanisms involved in these diseases. Recognition of occupational and environmental diseases, early diagnosis, mechanisms of cell injury and regeneration, and the effects of a wide variety of toxic drugs, chemicals and UV and ionizing radiation are included.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours.

Notes: PRIORITY INFORMATION IS ON BMSc WEBSITE:  http://www.schulich.uwo.ca/bmsc/academic_resources/courses/access_to_courses.html. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Pathology 3500 with a mark of at least 70% or the former Pathology 3240A and Pathology 3245B with a minimum mark of 70% in each.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 4425B - ADVANCED CLINICAL HISTOLOGY
Description: This course focuses on the microscopic evaluation and interpretation of tissue sections obtained from humans and animals. Lectures and laboratory sessions will examine select histology specimens obtained from healthy tissue/organs and from humans and animal models of disease.
Antirequisite(s): Anatomy and Cell Biology 4425A/B.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours, 2 laboratory hours.  Cross-listed with Anatomy and Cell Biology 4425A/B.

Notes: CROSS-LISTED WITH ANATCELL 4425B. PRIORITY INFORMATION IS ON BMSc WEBSITE:  http://www.schulich.uwo.ca/bmsc/academic_resources/courses/access_to_courses.html. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): A minimum mark of 70% in either Anatomy and Cell Biology 3309 or
Pathology 3500.
WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 4450A - MOLECULAR GENETICS HUMAN CANCR
Description: Mutation of specific human genes subverts normal cellular physiology creating characteristic alterations called ‘hallmarks’ that fuel the development of cancer. The underlying processes that alter cellular pathways and gene function will be discussed. Cancer models and molecular therapies will be related to the cancer hallmarks.
Antirequisite(s): Biochemistry 4450A.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours.
Cross-listed with Biochemistry 4450A.

Notes: CROSS-LISTED WITH BIOCHEM 4450A. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Biology 2581A/B; and either Pathology 3500 or Biochemistry 3381A.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 4500B - INTRODUCTION TO FORENSIC SCI
Description: Examination of the medicolegal framework investigating the nature and circumstance of certain deaths. These forensic investigations involve experts in different disciplines assisting the coroner and police in resolving cases. Forensic pathology examines the effects of disease, particularly in sudden death, and effects of various external agents on the human body.
Extra Information: 2 lecture hours.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO YR 4 HONORS SPECIALIZATION IN PATHOLOGY.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Pathology 3500 with a mark of at least 70% or the former Pathology 3240A and Pathology 3245B with a minimum mark of 70% in each.

Courses.Name: PATHOL 4980E - SEMINAR & RESEARCH PROJECT
Description: Includes: i) theory and practice of laboratory techniques, laboratory safety, appropriate use of experimental models, ii) an independent research project supervised by faculty, iii) oral and written communication skills, including the preparation of a research proposal and final written research project report.
Antirequisite(s): The former Pathology and Toxicology 4980E.
Extra Information: Minimum 11 laboratory hours per week plus 1 seminar hour per week.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO YR 4 HONS SPECIALIZATIONS IN PATHOLOGY, MICRO IMM WITH PATHOLOGY, BIOCHEM AND PATHOLOGY OF HUMAN DISEASE.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Pathology 3500 with a mark of at least 70% or the former Pathology 3240A and Pathology 3245B with marks of at least 70% in each; and one of the following: (Pharmacology 3620, Physiology 3120, and registration in Year 4 of the Honours Specialization in Pathology), (Microbiology and Immunology 3610F and Microbiology and Immunology 3620G with marks of at least 70% in each and registration in Year 4 of an Honours Specialization in Microbiology and Immunology with Pathology), or (Biochemistry 3380G with a mark of at least 70% and registration in Year 4 of an Honours Specialization in Biochemistry and Pathology of Human Disease).
